  I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

 
1. 
I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan to 
the  People’s  Republic  of  Bangladesh  for  the  additional  financing  of  the  Microenterprise 
Development Project.1  
 
2. 
The  ongoing  project  comprises  (i)  a  financial  intermediary  loan  of  $50  million  from  the 
ordinary capital resources of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for a credit line implemented by 
the Palli Karma-Sahayak Foundation (PKSF)—an apex development finance organization set up 
by  the  government—through  its  partner  microfinance  institutions  (MFIs);  and  (ii)  a  technical 
assistance (TA) grant of $500,000 to support microenterprise development. The entire $50 million 
loan  has  been  disbursed  to the PKSF,  which  has then  disbursed  it to  39,580  microenterprises 
through its 77 partner organizations, with an average loan size of $1,493, generating 91,430 rural 
jobs.2 The report and recommendation of the President for the current project is accessible from 
the list of linked documents in Appendix 2. 
 
3. 
activities of microenterprises, severely impacted by the coronavirus disease (COVID-19).  
 

The additional financing will scale up the ongoing project and help restore the economic 

II. 

THE PROJECT 

Rationale 

 
A. 
  
4. 
The  COVID-19  pandemic  has  severely  affected  the  lives  and  livelihoods  of  people  in 
Bangladesh. Many formal and informal workers in rural and urban areas have lost their livelihoods 
because of the pandemic and its associated economic shocks. Women have been heavily hit, as 
they  are  often  entrepreneurs  and  wage  earners  in  agriculture,  fisheries,  livestock,  small 
manufacturing, food processing, services, and trading. People living marginally above the poverty 
line are being pushed back into poverty as alternative employment opportunities are not available. 
Government support for wages to selected industry workers and cash subsidies to the urban poor, 
though  extremely  helpful  as  a  stopgap  measure,  cannot  be  sustained  over  long  periods. 
Employment generation, especially in rural areas, needs to be supported. 
 
Microenterprises,  with  their  large  employment  potential,  are  ideal  for  job  creation. 3 
5. 
However,  they  are  facing  working  capital  constraints,  supply  disruptions,  and  low  demand 
because of the COVID-19 economic slowdown; and their liquidity is severely constrained.4 This 
is affecting employment, production, and revenues. Women entrepreneurs who have experienced 
business losses do not have sufficient liquid assets, personal savings, or access to finance, so 
they have been forced to shut down or drastically scale down business operations.5 The PKSF

7. 
Suitability of using the additional financing modality. The proposed project meets the 
eligibility criteria for additional financing. The overall project is (i) technically feasible, economically 
viable, and financially sound; (ii) accorded high priority by the government; (iii) consistent with the 
project’s development objective; and (iv) consistent with ADB’s country operations business plan 
for Bangladesh, 2021–2023.9 The proposed additional financing is strongly linked to the ongoing 
project’s  outputs  and  outcome,  uses the  same  design  and  implementation  arrangements,  and 
builds on the lessons learned and due diligence of the ongoing project. 
 
8. 
Strategic  context.  The  project  is  aligned  with  the  government’s  National  Sustainable 
Development Strategy, 2010–2021, which promotes micro, small, and medium-sized enterprises 
to generate job opportunities.10 It is aligned with the operational priorities of ADB’s Strategy 2030 
to address remaining poverty and reduce inequalities, accelerate progress in gender equity, and 
promote  rural  development.11 It  is  also  aligned  with  ADB’s  country  partnership strategy,  2016–
2020, which identifies improving rural livelihoods and expanding employment opportunities as key 
priority areas.12 The project will complement support from other development partners.13

10. 
Output 1: Funding to microfinance institutions for microenterprise loans expanded. 
This output will provide a credit line to the PKSF for relending to its partner organizations to ease 
short-term  microenterprise  financing  constraints.  It  aims  to  provide  loans  to  at  least  30,000 
COVID-19 affected microenterprises who are eligible members of partner organizations, 70% of 
whom  are  female. 15 The  PKSF’s  microenterprise  total  loans  outstanding  will  be  Tk24  billion, 
almost double the 2017 baseline, with at least Tk5 billion for COVID-19 affected microenterprises. 
The  partner  organizations’  microenterprise  loan  portfolio  outstanding  will  reach  Tk160  billion, 
more than double the 2017 baseline, of which at least 70% are for female borrowers. To address 
medium-term  financing  constraints,  a  medium-term  institutional  strengthening  and  financing 
strategy for the PKSF was developed under the ongoing project. This is under discussion, and 
the PKSF will adopt the agreed recommendations. 
 
11. 
Output 2: Microfinance institutions’ capacity in microenterprise lending enhanced. 
This  output  will  enhance  MFI  capacity  in  microenterprise  lending  by  implementing  gender-
inclusive finance guidelines, improved under the ongoing project. Training (including refresher) 
will  be  provided  to  120  partner  organizations  using  the  microenterprise  finance  operational 
guidelines  developed  under the  ongoing  project. The  guidelines  include methodologies  for the 
credit  appraisal,  pricing,  terms  and  conditions,  and  financial  and  portfolio  management  and 
monitoring of MFIs’ microenterprise finance operations, including risk management. The mobile-
based microenterprise financing  application—pilot  tested for selected  partner  organizations  for 
activities such as loan applications, appraisal, disbursement, and collection—will be extended to 
three more partner organizations and 10,000 additional microenterprise borrowers, of whom at 
least  70%  are  female.  Legal  and  regulatory consultation,  application  development  or  adoption, 
guidelines and manual development, and partner organization and client training will continue.

Summary of Assessment 

the  COVID-19  pandemic.  The  project  will  directly benefit  at least  70,000 microenterprises  in 
Bangladesh,  of  which  70%  are  female  borrowers,  by  providing  a  reliable  and  affordable 
institutional source of finance. In doing so, the project greatly reduces the beneficiaries’ fund 
costs and promotes the efficient allocation of finance, thus yielding a higher rate of return to the 
beneficiaries’ microenterprise investments. 
The project is expected to enhance the sustainability of the PKSF’s operations, both financially 
and  institutionally.  The  ADB  loan  will  provide  a  credit  line  to  sustain  PKSF’s  funding  to 
microenterprises, and the ongoing TA will provide institutional strengthening to help the PKSF 
expand and sustain its operations. ADB’s long term funds will help the PKSF mobilize greater 
private sector finance to support sectors affected by COVID-19 by protecting and creating jobs.  
ADB  requirements  and  policies  on  financial  management  and  procurement  measures,  and 
environmental and social safeguards, were discussed and agreed with the government and the 
PKSF and incorporated in the project design. The specific requirements are described in the 
PAM.a Procurement will follow the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to 
time)  and  the  Procurement  Regulations  for  ADB  Borrowers  (2017, as  amended  from  time to 
time). Procurement will be undertaken by the individual beneficiary; fitness for purpose can be 
achieved by using established private sector and commercial practices. 
The financial management risk is moderate. Based on financial due diligence, the PKSF needs 
to  strengthen  its  capacity—particularly  its  management  information  system.  The  financial 
management  assessment,  which  includes  a  financial  analysis  of  partner  organizations, 
indicated  that  the  PKSF  has sufficient  experience in  managing  similar  projects  for  ADB  and 
other  international  development  partners  and  has  the  necessary  financial  management 
arrangements.  The  capacity  of  the  PKSF’s  partner  organizations  will  continue  to  be 
strengthened under the ongoing TA to improve the quality of their audit and financial statements, 
and portfolio management practices.  
ADB’s Anticorruption Policy (1998, as amended to date) was explained to and discussed with 
the government and the PKSF. The specific policy requirements and supplementary measures 
are described in the PAM.a 
The  project  will  support  microenterprises  that  can  be  key  drivers  of  rural  growth  and 
employment.  The  development  of  microenterprises  fosters  growth  through  forward  linkages, 
promotes product markets, and contributes to poverty alleviation by creating and protecting self- 
and wage-employment opportunities, which can significantly mitigate the impact of the COVID-
19 pandemic. The ongoing project has already created more than 90,000 jobs. The estimated 
monthly income of microenterprise workers in manufacturing, processing, or services ranges 
from  Tk4,000  for  part-time  workers  to  Tk15,000  for  full-time  workers.  Considering  that 
Bangladesh’s annual per capita gross national income in FY2017 was Tk127,401, the project is 
expected to contribute to poverty reduction by increasing rural household incomes. The project 
has a strong focus on developing women-led microenterprises and will develop MFI capacity in 
conducting women-focused microenterprise financing. It is classified gender equity as a theme.b 
The  project  will  be  implemented  following  ADB’s  Safeguard  Policy  Statement  (2009). 
Environment  (category  FI  treated  as  C).  The  project  is  expected  to  have  a  minimal 
environmental  impact  since  sub-loans  to  microenterprises  will  be  mainly  for  agriculture, 
fisheries, livestock, small manufacturing, food processing, services, and trade.c 
Involuntary  resettlement  (category  FI  treated  as  C).  Only  sub-loans  not  requiring  any 
involuntary resettlement will be financed.c  
Tribes, minor races, ethnic sects, and communities (category FI treated as C). Sub-loans 
are  for  activities  that  will  not  have  any  impact  on  tribes,  minor  races,  ethnic  sects,  and 
communities.    
The  PKSF  has  developed  environmental  and  social  screening  guidelines  for  partner 
organizations,  which  were  agreed  by  ADB.  Subproject  screening  will  be  mandatory  for 
implementation  by  all  partner  organizations  to  be  financed  under  the  project,  and  partner 
organizations will report on the status of the screening checklist to ADB through the PKSF. The 
partner  organizations  will  screen  all  subprojects  to  be  financed  under  the  project  to  ensure
